title: Cody Bellinger
text:
Cody James Bellinger (born July 13, 1995) is an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> and <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a> for the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB). He was selected by the Dodgers in the fourth round of the <a href="2013%20MLB%20draft">2013 MLB draft</a>, and debuted with the team in 2017.
The son of MLB player <a href="Clay%20Bellinger">Clay Bellinger</a>, Bellinger helped his team reach the <a href="2007%20Little%20League%20World%20Series">2007 Little League World Series</a> at the age of 11. He played high school baseball for <a href="Hamilton%20High%20School%20%28Chandler%2C%20Arizona%29">Hamilton High School</a> in <a href="Chandler%2C%20Arizona">Chandler, Arizona</a>, and had committed to play <a href="college%20baseball">college baseball</a> for the <a href="Oregon%20Ducks%20baseball">Oregon Ducks</a> before he was drafted. Bellinger spent two years in the <a href="Rookie%20League">Rookie League</a>s before joining the <a href="Rancho%20Cucamonga%20Quakes">Rancho Cucamonga Quakes</a> in 2015, where he was a mid- and postseason all-star, and helped the team to a <a href="California%20League">California League</a> championship title. A hip injury delayed his rise through the Dodgers' <a href="farm%20system">farm system</a> in 2016, but he was called up to the major leagues in April 2017 to bolster a struggling outfield.
Bellinger, setting a number of Dodgers single-season <a href="home%20run">home run</a> records, participated in both the <a href="2017%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game">2017 Major League Baseball All-Star Game</a> and in the <a href="Home%20Run%20Derby">Home Run Derby</a>, and he was named the <a href="National%20League">National League</a> (NL) <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year%20Award">Rookie of the Year</a> after the season. The following year, he was named the MVP of the <a href="2018%20National%20League%20Championship%20Series">2018 National League Championship Series</a> following an <a href="extra%20innings">extra innings</a> walk-off single that helped take the Dodgers to the <a href="2018%20World%20Series">2018 World Series</a>. He received the NL <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20Most%20Valuable%20Player%20Award">MVP</a>, <a href="Silver%20Slugger%20Award">Silver Slugger</a>, and <a href="Gold%20Glove%20Award">Gold Glove Award</a>s in 2019, as well as his second All-Star selection. Bellinger won his first <a href="World%20Series">World Series</a> title with the Dodgers in <a href="2020%20World%20Series">2020</a>. A number of injuries to his shoulder, calf, and rib cage, however, caused 2021 to be a career-worst year for Bellinger in home runs and <a href="batting%20average">batting average</a>.
Early life.
Bellinger was born on July 13, 1995, in <a href="Scottsdale%2C%20Arizona">Scottsdale, Arizona</a>, to <a href="Clay%20Bellinger">Clay</a> and Jennifer Bellinger. His mother works for <a href="Sotheby%27s%20International%20Realty">Sotheby's International Realty</a>, while his father played for the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a> and <a href="Anaheim%20Angels">Anaheim Angels</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) from 1999 to 2002, winning three <a href="World%20Series">World Series</a> in that span. Clay Bellinger also coached the <a href="Chandler%2C%20Arizona">Chandler, Arizona</a> National Little League team, for whom his son played when they went to the <a href="2007%20Little%20League%20World%20Series">2007 Little League World Series</a> (LLWS). Cody was only 11 years old at the time, one year younger than most of his LLWS teammates, but he helped to clinch a berth in the series with a four-<a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a> (RBI) performance in the Little League West Regional. Chandler advanced to the LLWS in <a href="Williamsport%2C%20Pennsylvania">Williamsport, Pennsylvania</a>, but was eliminated in the semifinals by teams from <a href="Lubbock%2C%20Texas">Lubbock, Texas</a> and <a href="Warner%20Robins%2C%20Georgia">Warner Robins, Georgia</a>.
A few years later, Bellinger became a standout baseball player for <a href="Hamilton%20High%20School%20%28Chandler%2C%20Arizona%29">Hamilton High School</a> in Chandler. He was voted team MVP as both a <a href="Junior%20%28education%29">junior</a> and as a <a href="Senior%20%28education%29">senior</a>, and <a href="Batting%20average">hit</a> .429 in his senior season. Although <a href="Scout%20%28sports%29">scouts</a> from the Yankees invited Bellinger to a pre-draft practice, most baseball teams were uninterested in using a high draft pick on Bellinger, who stood but weighed only in his final year of high school, and who hit only one home run that season.
Professional career.
Draft and minor leagues.
The <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a> selected Bellinger in the fourth round, 124th overall, of the <a href="2013%20MLB%20Draft">2013 MLB Draft</a>. At the time, he had committed to play <a href="college%20baseball">college baseball</a> for the <a href="Oregon%20Ducks%20baseball">Oregon Ducks</a>. Bellinger chose to forego his commitment to Oregon in order to sign with the Dodgers for a <a href="signing%20bonus">signing bonus</a> of $700,000, approximately $300,000 more than what was recommended for a fourth-round draft pick. He spent the season with the <a href="Rookie%20League">Rookie League</a> <a href="AZL%20Dodgers">AZL Dodgers</a>, batting .210 in 162 at-bats, with one home run, 30 RBIs, and 25 runs scored. He showed some difficulties with plate discipline, striking out 46 times in 47 games, but showed potential by drawing 31 walks and recording 16 extra-base hits. He continued in Rookie ball the following season with the <a href="Ogden%20Raptors">Ogden Raptors</a>, batting .328 with 34 RBIs in 46 <a href="Pioneer%20League%20%28baseball%29">Pioneer League</a> games.
Assigned to the <a href="Class%20A-Advanced">Class A-Advanced</a> <a href="Rancho%20Cucamonga%20Quakes">Rancho Cucamonga Quakes</a>, the 2015 season was Bellinger's first full year in the <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">minor leagues</a>. His prospect performance started to gain attention when, by June 11, he was fifth in the <a href="California%20League">California League</a> with 12 home runs, and was at least three years younger than every other top-five hitter. Although his .557 <a href="slugging%20percentage">slugging percentage</a> was comparatively low, this was due in part to the shape of the <a href="Rancho%20Cucamonga%20Epicenter">Rancho Cucamonga Epicenter</a>, which limited home runs. After making an appearance at the midseason California League All-Star Game, Bellinger was also the selected <a href="designated%20hitter">designated hitter</a> for the California League postseason All-Star team. Following the regular minor league season, he helped the Quakes to a Cal League championship title, registering three extra-base hits, including the game-winning home run, to complete their sweep of the <a href="San%20Jose%20Giants">San Jose Giants</a>. For his performance, Bellinger was named the California League Championship Series <a href="Most%20Valuable%20Player">MVP</a>. He batted .264 for the Quakes, recording 30 home runs, 103 RBIs, and 97 runs in 478 at bats.
After a strong <a href="spring%20training">spring training</a> performance in which he batted .393 in 18 games, Bellinger opened the 2016 season with the <a href="Double-A%20%28baseball%29">Double-A</a> <a href="Tulsa%20Drillers">Tulsa Drillers</a> of the <a href="Texas%20League">Texas League</a>. He missed the first part of the Double-A season with a strained hip, and upon returning from the <a href="disabled%20list">disabled list</a> in May, Bellinger struggled to make contact, batting .150 through his first 50 at-bats. His drought snapped on May 16, with a walk-off grand slam against the <a href="Arkansas%20Travelers">Arkansas Travelers</a>. He spent the bulk of the season in Tulsa, batting .263 with 23 home runs and 65 RBIs in 114 games, but was promoted to the <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a> <a href="Oklahoma%20City%20Dodgers">Oklahoma City Dodgers</a> on September 3, in advance of the <a href="Pacific%20Coast%20League">Pacific Coast League</a> playoffs. He played in only three games for Oklahoma City that season, recording three home runs and six RBIs in the process. Having missed a month of the season with his injured hip, Bellinger played for the <a href="Glendale%20Desert%20Dogs">Glendale Desert Dogs</a> of the <a href="Arizona%20Fall%20League">Arizona Fall League</a>, earning All-Fall League team honors. In 20 games with Glendale, Bellinger hit .314 with three home runs, eight doubles, and 17 RBIs, and he was named a member of the AFL Top Prospects Team.
During the 2016–17 MLB offseason, Bellinger and fellow Dodgers prospect <a href="Jose%20De%20Leon">Jose De Leon</a> received an invitation to the MLB/MLBPA Rookie Career Development Program in <a href="Leesburg%2C%20Virginia">Leesburg, Virginia</a>, where top prospects from each club spend four days learning about life in the major leagues. He began the 2017 season with Oklahoma City, batting .343 with five home runs and 15 RBIs in the first 18 games of the year before receiving a call-up to Los Angeles.
Los Angeles Dodgers.
2017: NL Rookie of the Year and World Series.
Faced with a struggling and injured outfield, the Dodgers called Bellinger up on April 25, 2017, giving him the start in left field and eighth position in the <a href="Batting%20order%20%28baseball%29">batting order</a> for that night's game against the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Giants">San Francisco Giants</a>. Bellinger scored his first major league hit that night, an infield ground ball towards third base. He was also the third Dodger since 1913 to be <a href="Intentional%20base%20on%20balls">intentionally walked</a> in his MLB debut, following <a href="Chico%20Fern%C3%A1ndez">Chico Fernández</a> in 1956 and <a href="Dick%20Nen">Dick Nen</a> in 1963. Four days later, Bellinger hit the first and second home runs of his major league career in a game against the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a>, first in the seventh inning against <a href="Zach%20Eflin">Zach Eflin</a> and again as the second of three consecutive home runs against <a href="Closer%20%28baseball%29">closer</a> <a href="H%C3%A9ctor%20Neris">Héctor Neris</a>. His first career <a href="Grand%20slam%20%28baseball%29">grand slam</a> came the following week on May 6, helping take the Dodgers to a 10–2 victory over the <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a> and Bellinger to five home runs and 14 RBIs in his first 11 major league games. With a total of nine home runs in the month of May, Bellinger tied <a href="Joc%20Pederson">Joc Pederson</a> and <a href="James%20Loney">James Loney</a> for the most home runs by a Dodgers rookie in one month of the season, and his total of 11 home runs in 32 games made him the fastest Dodgers rookie in history to reach that mark.
A series of multi-home run games in the month of June helped Bellinger to set several team and MLB records. On June 13, Bellinger became the fastest player in MLB history to record four multi-home run games, doing so in 45 contests; the previous record was set by <a href="Bob%20Horner">Bob Horner</a> with 63 games in 1978. He was also the first Dodger to have consecutive multi-home run games since <a href="Adri%C3%A1n%20Beltr%C3%A9">Adrián Beltré</a> in 2004, and was the third Dodgers rookie to record at least four multi-home run games in one season. In the first inning of an outing against the <a href="New%20York%20Mets">New York Mets</a> on June 19, his 51st career MLB game, Bellinger tied <a href="Gary%20S%C3%A1nchez">Gary Sánchez</a> and <a href="Wally%20Berger">Wally Berger</a> as the fastest players to reach 20 home runs. The next inning, he recorded an additional solo shot against <a href="Zack%20Wheeler">Zack Wheeler</a> to become the fastest player to 21 home runs. The following day, a first-inning hit off of <a href="Robert%20Gsellman">Robert Gsellman</a> helped Bellinger to become the first rookie in MLB history to record 10 home runs in a span of 10 games. With his sixth two-home run game of the season on June 25, Bellinger passed <a href="Mike%20Piazza">Mike Piazza</a>'s team rookie record for most multi-home run games in one season, and led the NL with 24 total home runs. He capped off the first half of the season with his first appearances in both the <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game">Major League Baseball All-Star Game</a> and in the <a href="Home%20Run%20Derby">Home Run Derby</a>. At the latter, Bellinger hit 27 home runs across two rounds, defeating <a href="Charlie%20Blackmon">Charlie Blackmon</a> before falling to <a href="Aaron%20Judge">Aaron Judge</a> of the Yankees in the semifinals.
While facing the <a href="Miami%20Marlins">Miami Marlins</a> on July 15, Bellinger became the first Dodgers rookie in history to <a href="hit%20for%20the%20cycle">hit for the cycle</a>, going 4-for-5 with a home run, three RBIs, and two runs. With his 35th home run of the year on September 2, Bellinger tied Mike Piazza's Dodgers rookie record; he broke Piazza's record the following day with a ninth-inning shot off of Padres closer <a href="Brad%20Hand">Brad Hand</a>. On September 22, Bellinger's 39th career home run both helped the Dodgers clinch the <a href="NL%20West">NL West</a> title over the San Francisco Giants and broke Wally Berger and <a href="Frank%20Robinson">Frank Robinson</a>'s record for the most <a href="National%20League">National League</a> (NL) home runs made by a rookie. Bellinger finished his rookie MLB season hitting .267 with 39 home runs, 97 RBIs, and 87 <a href="runs%20scored">runs scored</a> in 480 <a href="at%20bat">at bat</a>s and 132 games.
Bellinger's first MLB postseason began with the <a href="2017%20National%20League%20Division%20Series">2017 National League Division Series</a> (NLDS) against the <a href="Arizona%20Diamondbacks">Arizona Diamondbacks</a>, where his fifth-inning solo home run in Game 3 made him the youngest Dodger to hit a postseason home run in franchise history. His next postseason home run came against <a href="Jake%20Arrieta">Jake Arrieta</a> of the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> in Game 4 of the <a href="2018%20National%20League%20Championship%20Series">2018 National League Championship Series</a> (NLCS); in doing so, he became the youngest player to homer in a Championship Series game since the 20-year-old <a href="Miguel%20Cabrera">Miguel Cabrera</a> did so in Game 7 of the <a href="2003%20National%20League%20Championship%20Series">2003 NLCS</a>. Outside of home runs, however, Bellinger did not generate many hits: with three <a href="strikeout">strikeout</a>s in Game 7 of the <a href="2017%20World%20Series">2017 World Series</a>, Bellinger set the MLB record with 29 strikeouts in a single postseason run. Despite the Dodgers falling to the <a href="Houston%20Astros">Houston Astros</a> in the World Series, Bellinger was the unanimous winner of the NL <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year%20Award">Rookie of the Year Award</a>.
2018: NLCS MVP and World Series.
As he entered the <a href="2018%20MLB%20season">2018 MLB season</a>, Bellinger was unfazed by the concept of a <a href="sophomore%20slump">sophomore slump</a>, in which an athlete's performance falters during their second professional season. He hit the first home run of the season, a two-run shot off of <a href="Rich%20Hill%20%28pitcher%29">Rich Hill</a> of the Giants to spur the Dodgers to a 9–0 victory and end Bellinger's opening 0-for-11 skid. That home run was also the 40th of Bellinger's career. He accomplished the feat in 136 games, making him the third-fastest MLB player to reach 40 career home runs. Bellinger was unable to sustain his rookie momentum through the start of June, however, and when manager <a href="Dave%20Roberts%20%28outfielder%29">Dave Roberts</a> benched him on June 3, there were questions that Bellinger would be <a href="Option%20%28baseball%29">optioned</a> back to the minors. Bellinger, meanwhile, used the benching to make a small adjustment to his stance in the batter's box, and he proceeded to record six hits in his next 13 at-bats, including home runs in four consecutive games. He played in all 162 regular-season games that year, batting .260 with 25 home runs and 76 RBIs in 557 at bats.
Bellinger helped the Dodgers to capture the NL West title with the go-ahead two-run home run in a tiebreaker game against the <a href="Colorado%20Rockies">Colorado Rockies</a> on October 1. Once the Dodgers reached the 2018 postseason, however, he began to slump, not recording a hit in the four-game <a href="2018%20National%20League%20Division%20Series">NLDS</a> against the <a href="Atlanta%20Braves">Atlanta Braves</a>. Although he did not hit often during the <a href="2018%20National%20League%20Championship%20Series">NLCS</a> against the <a href="Milwaukee%20Brewers">Milwaukee Brewers</a>, the hits that Bellinger did have were impactful: his 10th-inning jumping catch in Game 4 kept the Dodgers alive, while a 13th-inning single in led the Dodgers towards a walk-off win. After hitting the go-ahead home run in Game 7 that clinched the National League pennant for the Dodgers, Bellinger was named the <a href="League%20Championship%20Series%20Most%20Valuable%20Player%20Award">NLCS MVP</a> for the 2018 season. Despite receiving his NLCS honor, Bellinger started only two games in the <a href="2018%20World%20Series">2018 World Series</a>, with manager <a href="Dave%20Roberts%20%28outfielder%29">Dave Roberts</a> preferring to <a href="Platoon%20system">platoon</a> almost every position. He successfully reached base only once in the five-game series, on a single, and was later <a href="caught%20stealing">caught stealing</a>. The Dodgers lost the World Series to the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> in five games, and Bellinger was benched in the elimination game, giving the right-handed <a href="Enrique%20Hern%C3%A1ndez%20%28baseball%29">Enrique Hernández</a> the start against left-handed Boston pitcher <a href="David%20Price%20%28baseball%29">David Price</a>.
2019: NL MVP, Gold Glove and Silver Slugger.
Bellinger started the 2019 season on a hot streak, leading MLB in runs, hits, batting average, and slugging percentage by the end of April. His 13th home run of the season came on April 27, breaking <a href="Matt%20Kemp">Matt Kemp</a>'s record for the most single-season home runs of any Dodger through the end of April. The home run also lifted Bellinger to 88 <a href="total%20bases">total bases</a> by the end of April, three more than <a href="Chase%20Utley">Chase Utley</a>'s 2008 record and the most of any batter in the <a href="live-ball%20era">live-ball era</a>. His 97 total bases, 37 RBIs, and 47 hits before May 1 were all MLB records, while his 32 runs scored and 14 home runs tied existing records. Batting .431 in 132 plate appearances, Bellinger received his first <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20Player%20of%20the%20Month%20Award">Player of the Month</a> honors for April 2019.
By the All-Star break, Bellinger and <a href="Christian%20Yelich">Christian Yelich</a> of the Milwaukee Brewers were the frontrunners for the NL <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20Most%20Valuable%20Player%20Award">MVP Award</a>. Bellinger led with 72 runs, 73 RBIs, a .334 average, and a .431 <a href="on-base%20percentage">on-base percentage</a>, while his 31 home runs, .687 slugging percentage, and 1.118 <a href="on-base%20plus%20slugging">on-base plus slugging</a> (OPS) were all slightly behind Yelich. Bellinger also led MLB with 6.7 <a href="Wins%20Above%20Replacement">Wins Above Replacement</a>. Bellinger received both his second All-Star game nod and his first All-Star start in 2019, opening the game in the NL outfield with Yelich and with <a href="Ronald%20Acu%C3%B1a%20Jr.">Ronald Acuña Jr.</a> of the Atlanta Braves. He also received an invitation to that year's Home Run Derby, but turned it down in order to have a day off from baseball before the All-Star game.
During a particularly frustrating <a href="Freeway%20Series">Freeway Series</a> game on July 24, Bellinger received his first MLB game ejection after arguing with home plate umpire <a href="Dan%20Iassogna">Dan Iassogna</a> over balls and strikes. Bellinger justified his decision by saying, "I'm trying to do the best I can to get on base, and it's hard to hit like that." On August 2, Bellinger hit his 100th career home run off of <a href="Eric%20Lauer">Eric Lauer</a> of the San Diego Padres; he did so in only his 401st game, breaking Mike Piazza's Dodgers record of 422 games to 100 home runs. Two weeks later, Bellinger became both the first MLB player of the 2019 season and the youngest Dodger in franchise history to record his 40th home run of the year. Outside of these records, Bellinger's production began to slow after the All-Star break; he batted just .256 in the second half of the season, with a .906 OPS and only 13 home runs in the final 51 games of the year. Part of this was due to conversations with Dodgers staff about ignoring the MVP race in favor of staying calm and building to the postseason. Additionally, pitchers began avoiding throwing <a href="Strike%20zone">strikes</a> to Bellinger where possible; he had 86 walks by September 5, a league-leading 19 of which were <a href="Intentional%20walk">intentional</a>. During that year's <a href="2019%20National%20League%20Division%20Series">NLDS</a>, the <a href="Washington%20Nationals">Washington Nationals</a> bullpen capitalized on areas where Bellinger was comparatively weaker: he faced predominantly left-handed pitchers, who avoided throwing middle-of-the-road fastballs in favor of low and outside pitches that would let Bellinger either swing and miss, <a href="In%20flight">foul out</a>, or take a <a href="Base%20on%20balls">walk</a>.
Bellinger finished the 2019 season with career highs in batting average (.305), home runs (47), and RBIs (115). He also received a trifecta of MLB awards, taking home the MVP award, the NL <a href="Gold%20Glove%20Award">Gold Glove Award</a>, and the NL <a href="Silver%20Slugger%20Award">Silver Slugger Award</a>. He was the first Dodger in club history to take home all three honors in the same season. He also received two <a href="Fielding%20Bible%20Award">Fielding Bible Award</a>s for his performance both in right field and as a multi-positional player in right field, center field, and at first base. With these titles, he became the first Dodgers outfielder to win any Fielding Bible Award and the first MLB player to pick up two in the same season. Bellinger rounded out the 2019 awards season with a selection to the inaugural <a href="All-MLB%20Team">All-MLB First Team</a>, joining Yelich and <a href="Mike%20Trout">Mike Trout</a> in the outfield.
2020: World Series championship.
During the 2019–20 MLB offseason, Bellinger signed an $11,5 million contract with the Dodgers for the 2020 season, breaking <a href="Kris%20Bryant">Kris Bryant</a>'s record for the largest single-season contract for a player in his first year eligible for <a href="arbitration">arbitration</a>. When MLB announced the indefinite suspension of the <a href="2020%20MLB%20season">2020 season</a> due to the <a href="Impact%20of%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic%20on%20sports">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, Bellinger went back to Arizona and focused on tweaking his swing in a "stress-free environment". When the pandemic-shortened season began, Bellinger had a slow start, going 5-for-36 in his first eight games. Unlike in previous years, Bellinger was making weak contact with pitches, leading to a large number of groundouts. His numbers for the whole season saw a drop-off from the previous year: in 56 games of the shortened season, Bellinger hit only .239, with a .789 OPS and only 12 home runs. The 2020 season proved to be a struggle for many of MLB's top hitters: five of the 15 batters who showed the largest drop in slugging percentage were previous MVP winners or finalists, including Bellinger. Bellinger's drops in batting average and slugging percentage, the latter of which fell from .670 in 2019 to .354 in 2020, was explained by his constant experimentation with his swing, which prevented him from locking into pitches the way he had the season prior. Bellinger was once again a finalist for a Gold Glove Award in the outfield, but the award ultimately went to <a href="Trent%20Grisham">Trent Grisham</a> of the San Diego Padres.
The Dodgers were the first team to clinch a playoff berth in the 2020 season, developing a commanding lead over the NL West by September 16. They finished at the top of their division and went on to sweep the Brewers at the <a href="2020%20National%20League%20Wild%20Card%20Series">2020 National League Wild Card Series</a>. From there, the Dodgers faced the Padres in the <a href="2020%20National%20League%20Division%20Series">2020 NLDS</a>, where Bellinger's defensive play in Game 2 allowed Los Angeles to hang onto their 4–3 lead and take the game. In the seventh inning, with Grisham on second base, Bellinger made a jumping catch to rob <a href="Fernando%20Tatis%20Jr.">Fernando Tatis Jr.</a> of a two-run home run. The <a href="2020%20National%20League%20Championship%20Series">2020 NLCS</a> started with the Dodgers down 3–1 in four games, but they were able to mount a comeback and push the series to seven games. Bellinger scored the go-ahead home run in that final game, clinching the Dodgers' place in the <a href="2020%20World%20Series">2020 World Series</a>. There, the Dodgers defeated the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Rays">Tampa Bay Rays</a> in six games for Bellinger's first World Series championship and the Dodgers' first since 1988. Despite injuring his shoulder during the NLCS, Bellinger continued to play in the World Series, and he celebrated his Game 1 home run by foot-tapping his teammates rather than high-fiving them. After the season, Bellinger signed a one-year, $16.1 million contract with the Dodgers for the 2021 season.
2021: Injuries and slump.
Bellinger, who had repeatedly injured his right shoulder by diving for ground balls throughout his professional baseball career, underwent surgery for the affected arm in November 2020. He revealed later that, while celebrating his NLCS-winning home run that October, he had dislocated his shoulder by connecting too strongly with teammate <a href="Enrique%20Hern%C3%A1ndez%20%28baseball%29">Enrique Hernández</a>' arm. Bellinger's recovery from the <a href="Arthroscopy">arthroscopic</a> <a href="glenoid%20labrum">glenoid labrum</a> surgery progressed ahead of schedule, and he was able to join the Dodgers for spring training in 2021. He suffered another serious injury on April 6 after colliding with <a href="Oakland%20Athletics">Oakland Athletics</a> pitcher <a href="Reymin%20Guduan">Reymin Guduan</a>. Bellinger was initially placed on the 10-day injured list before medical scans revealed that he had suffered a <a href="hairline%20fracture">hairline fracture</a> in his left <a href="fibula">fibula</a>. He returned on May 29, going 0-for-4 with two strikeouts in an 11–6 loss to the Giants, but a sixth-inning walk allowed Bellinger to extend his on-base streak to 20 games.
Bellinger's return from injury was marked by a career-worst offensive performance. In his first 11 games back, he struck out 14 times while recording only one extra-base hit. While his defense remained sharp in center field, by July 23, Bellinger was batting under .200 both at home and on the road. He admitted in August that his poor batting was due to lingering pain and weakness from both the shoulder and leg injuries, and Bellinger's batting grew stronger as he continued to exercise the affected areas. At the end of the month, Roberts made the decision to relegate Bellinger to a <a href="Platoon%20system">platoon</a> role in the outfield, starting <a href="A.%20J.%20Pollock">A. J. Pollock</a>, <a href="Mookie%20Betts">Mookie Betts</a>, or <a href="Chris%20Taylor%20%28baseball%29">Chris Taylor</a> against left-handed pitchers. Injuries to Pollock and Taylor, however, forced the Dodgers to renege on that platoon system shortly after its introduction. Bellinger suffered his third major injury of the season in September, when a collision with teammate <a href="Gavin%20Lux">Gavin Lux</a> resulted in a fractured rib. By the time of the collision, Bellinger had already missed 46 games that season with his fractured fibula, and an additional seven with hamstring tightness. Bellinger finished the regular season batting a career-low .165, with ten home runs and 36 RBIs in 315 at bats.
In the <a href="2021%20National%20League%20Wild%20Card%20Game">Wild Card Game</a> against the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a>, he reached base three times and stole twice. In Game 2 of the <a href="2021%20National%20League%20Division%20Series">NLDS</a> match against division rivals the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Giants">San Francisco Giants</a>, Bellinger's two-RBI double provided the go-ahead runs for an ultimate 9–2 rout of San Francisco. Bellinger's game-winning RBI single in Game 5 of the NLDS not only helped the Dodgers to defeat the Giants and advance to the NLCS, but it helped him tie <a href="Manny%20Ramirez">Manny Ramirez</a> and <a href="Gene%20Tenace">Gene Tenace</a>'s record of three career go-ahead hits in winner-take-all games. In Game 3 of the <a href="2021%20National%20League%20Championship%20Series">NLCS</a>, the Dodgers were down 5–2 against the <a href="Atlanta%20Braves">Atlanta Braves</a> when Bellinger hit a three-run home run in the eighth inning. After Bellinger tied the game and cleared the bases, a single and stolen base from <a href="Chris%20Taylor%20%28baseball%29">Chris Taylor</a>, followed by an RBI double from <a href="Mookie%20Betts">Mookie Betts</a>, helped the Dodgers win the game 6–5. The home run pitch from <a href="Luke%20Jackson%20%28baseball%29">Luke Jackson</a>, a <a href="fastball">fastball</a>, crossed the plate while above the ground, making it very difficult to hit. It was Bellinger's first home run of the season that had been thrown outside the <a href="strike%20zone">strike zone</a>. Dave Roberts told reporters after the game that "it's just hard to imagine a bigger hit". Although the Dodgers went on to lose to the Braves in six games, Bellinger recorded 12 hits and seven RBIs in 34 postseason at bats.
Batting style.
Bellinger, originally much weaker while batting than fielding, became a <a href="power%20hitter">power hitter</a> after making a change to his batting stance during the 2014–15 offseason. Working with <a href="Shawn%20Wooten">Shawn Wooten</a> and <a href="Damon%20Mashore">Damon Mashore</a>, Bellinger incorporated a small hand and wrist movement into his "load phase", which prepared him to make strong contact with the ball. In response to concerns that he was "standing too tall and straight-legged" in the batter's box during the 2018 season, making it difficult to build momentum, Bellinger made a number of other changes during the 2018–19 offseason, including adopting a more relaxed position at the plate and aiming to hit under <a href="breaking%20ball">breaking ball</a>s rather than over. These changes, coupled with showing greater discretion in choosing when to swing, helped Bellinger make contact more frequently and with greater power during his MVP season.
Personal life.
Bellinger has one brother, Cole, who is four years his junior. A standout <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> for Hamilton High School, Cole was selected by the San Diego Padres in the 15th round of the <a href="2017%20MLB%20Draft">2017 MLB Draft</a>. Cole played for two seasons in the Padres farm system before retiring from baseball in 2021. Bellinger has one child with girlfriend and model <a href="Chase%20Carter">Chase Carter</a>: daughter Caiden Carter Bellinger, born November 2021.
A character inspired by Bellinger makes a <a href="cameo%20appearance">cameo appearance</a> in the video game "<a href="Assassin%27s%20Creed%20Valhalla">Assassin's Creed Valhalla</a>". The player character must defeat <a href="Viking">Viking</a> Otta Sluggasson, who wields a tree trunk like a baseball bat, during one story section. Bellinger, an avid gamer, recorded his movements using <a href="motion%20capture">motion capture</a> technology, with his own baseball bat serving as Sluggasson's weapon.
